questions.question_text:
Your organization has deployed a large, complex application across multiple compute instances in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). These compute instances also have block volume storage attached to them. You want to create a time consistent backup of this block volume storage.
Which implementation strategy should be used?

discussion.content:
Question says - "time consistent backup"; so manual is not an option. (not D)
I think I should be "C". - Group Volumn for better management, and CLI for automation (time consistancy).

comments.content: A manual backup produces the same result as the automatic backup, with the only difference being that you do it whenever you want.

discussion.content: correct is D

D)
“This simplifies the process to create time-consistent backups of running enterprise applications that span multiple storage volumes across multiple instances.”

https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/volumegroups.htm
D is correct.
D is the right answer
C is right
Volume Group, Manual Backup - "D"

Correct answer is D:
The Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Block Volume service provides you with the capability to group together multiple volumes in a volume group. A volume group can include both types of volumes, boot volumes, which are the system disks for your Compute instances, and block volumes for your data storage. You can use volume groups to create volume group backups and clones that are pointin-time and crash-consistent.
This simplifies the process to create time-consistent backups of running enterprise applications that span multiple storage volumes across multiple instances. You can then restore an entire group of volumes from a volume group backup.
To create a backup of the volume group
Open the navigation menu. Under Core Infrastructure, go to Block Storage and click Volumes Groups. In the Volume Groups list, click Create Volume Group Backup in the Actions menu for the volume group you want to create a backup for.

correct is D To create a backup of the volume group
Open the navigation menu. Under Core Infrastructure, go to Block Storage and click Volumes Groups.
In the Volume Groups list, click Create Volume Group Backup in the Actions menu for the volume group you want to create a backup for. (time consistancy) Apply for both manual o cli,res, etc. and is not script is command.

Ans: D
C is false because there are no available scripts in OCI. We need to create script manually.
Correct answer is C.
Correct is B : there is only 1 BV : These compute instances also have block volume storage attached to them

choices.D: Group volumes in a volume group and create a manual backup of the volume group
choices.B: Use scripts available in OCI to backup block volume storage
choices.A: Create a manual backup of each volume
choices.C: Group volumes in a volume group first and then use available scripts in OCI

choices.B: locally attached NVMe on virtual machine
choices.D: object storage on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure

questions.question_text: Which two resources reside exclusively in a single availability domain? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Agree with AE.

B is for letting users access stuff.
C doesnt make sense.
D is for internet access.
A, E are the correct options
A and e

choices.E: The route table associated with subnets in each VCN do not have a route rule defined to forward the traffic to their respective DRGs
choices.D: An internet gateway needs to be created in each VCN with a default route rule added in the route table forwarding the traffic to the internet gateway
choices.A: The security lists associated with subnets in each virtual cloud network (VCN) do not have the appropriate ingress rules
choices.B: Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies have not been defined to allow connectivity across the two VCNs in different regions
choices.C: A local peering gateway needs to be created in each VCN with a default route rule added in the route table forwarding the traffic to the local peering gateway

questions.question_text:
You are designing a networking infrastructure in multiple Oracle Cloud Infrastructure regions and require connectivity between workloads in each region. You have created a dynamic routing gateway (DRG) and a remote peering connection. However, your workloads are unable to communicate with each other.
What are two reasons for this? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: D is ans if Aa is the answer it would have not even recieved the traffic in the first place

D is the answer. Previous sessions that went to the heavily loaded machine are still going there making it loaded even more.

A is incorrect, like the other guy said.

Its possible that due to "Session Persistence" one instance may be receiving more traffic, but disabling the same is not a solution, as session persistence is there for a reason (provide continuity to users). So A seems to be the best choice.

It's possible that due to "Session Persistence" specific instance may receive more connection, but disabling that is not a solution, as session persistence is provided for a reason (to user not to loose the continuity). So A seems to be the right option.

D is correct
"The Load Balancing service calculates a hash of the configured cookie and other request parameters, and sends that value to the client in a cookie. The value stored in the cookie enables the service to route subsequent client requests to the correct backend server."
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Balance/Reference/sessionpersistence.htm
I am going with D too
D is right
D - Disable Session Persistance
It's so obviously "D", but smoking game is strong in this entire questionnaire.
Is D Correct ??? : https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Balance/Reference/sessionpersistence.htm

choices.D: Disable session persistence on your backend set
choices.A: Check security lists and route tables of your virtual cloud network (VCN) and fix any issues associated with the rules
choices.C: Delete and re-create your OCI load balancer
choices.B: Create separate listeners for each backend web server

questions.question_text:
You have an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) load balancer distributing traffic via an evenly-weighted round robin policy to your backend web servers. You notice that one of your web servers is receiving more traffic than other web servers.
How can you resolve this imbalance?
